titleStmt.title: THE First part of the Contention betwixt the two famous Houses of Yorke and Lancaster, with the death of the good Duke Humphrey: And the banishment and death of the Duke of Suffolke, and the Tragicall end of the proud Cardinall of Winchester, with the notable Rebellion of Iacke Cade: And the Duke of Yorkes first claime unto the Crowne.

respStmt.name: Tanmay Shah and homographed and regularised by Alexis Antonia

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by Thomas Creed, for Thomas Millington, and are to be sold at his shop vnder Saint Peters Church in Cornwall.

editorialDecl.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations.
Earl of Suffolk Henry VI Queen Margaret Humphrey Duke of Gloucester, brother to the King Winchester Henry Beaufort, great-uncle to Henry V, bishop of Winchster, and later cardinal Duke of Buckingham Duke/Earl of Somerset Earl of Salisbury Earl of Warwick Richard Plantagenet (Duke of Gloucester) becomes duke of York Eleanor, duchess of Gloucester Messenger Father John Hume, a priest First Petitioner Second Petitioner Peter, Thomas Horner's man Thomas Horner, an armourer Margaret Jourdain, a witch Bolingbroke, a conjurer Spirit Servant Simpcox, an imposter All Simpcox's Wife Mayor of Saint Alban's Beadle Both (Earl of Salisbury and Earl of Warwick) First Neighbour Second Neighbour Third Neighbour First Prentise Second Prentise Third Prentise Herald Sheriff Sir John Stanley First Murderer Second Murderer Vawse Captain Walter Whitmore First Prisoner Second Prisoner Maister Nicke, a follower of Cade George Bevis, a follower of Cade Jack Cade, a rebel Dick the Butcher, a follower of Cade Robin, a follower of Cade Will, a follower of Cade Clerk of Chatham Tom Sir Humphrey Stafford Reade Lord Say Lord Scales First Citizen Soldier Sargiant Lord Clifford Alexander Iden, a Kentish gentleman King Edward IV (Plantagenet) Richard Plantagenet the Younger Young Clifford

div1.head: THE FIRST PART OF THE CONTENTION OF THE TWO FAMOVS Houses of Yorke and Lancaster, with the death of the good Duke Humphrey.

div2.stage: Enter at one doore, King Henry the sixt, and Humphrey Duke of Gloster, the Duke of Sommerset, the Duke of Buckingham, Cardinall Bewford, and others. Enter at the other doore, the Duke of Yorke, and the Marquesse of Suffolke, and Queene Margaret, and the Earle of Salisbury and Warwicke.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: AS by your high imperial Majesties command,
I had in charge at my depart for France,
As Procurator for your excellence,
To marry Princes Margaret for your grace,
So in the ancient famous City Towers,
In presence of the Kings of France and Cyssile,
The Dukes of Orleance, Calabar, Brittaine, and Alonson.
Seven Earls, twelve Barons, and then the reverend Bishops,
I did perform my task and was espoused,
And now, most humbly on my bended knees,
In sight of England and her royal Peers,
Deliver up my title in the Queen,
Unto your gracious excellence, that are the substance
Of that great shadow I did represent:
The happiest gift that ever Marquess gave,
The fairest Queen that ever King possessed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Suffolke arise.
Welcome Queen Margaret to English Henries Court,
The greatest show of kindness yet we can bestow,
Is this kind kiss: O gracious God of heaven,
Lend me a heart replete with thankfulness,
For in this beauteous face thou hast bestowed
A world of pleasures to my perplexed soul.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: The excessive love I bear unto your grace,
Forbids me to be lavish of my tongue,
Lest I should speak more than beseems a woman:
Let this suffice, my bliss is in your liking,
And nothing can make poor Margaret miserable,
Unless the frown of mighty Englands King.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Her looks did wound, but now her speech doth pierce,
Lovely Queen Margaret sit down by my side:
And uncle Gloster, and you Lordly Peers,
With one voice welcome my beloved Queen.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Long live Queen Margaret, Englands happiness.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: We thank you all.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: My Lord Protector, so it please your grace,
Here are the Articles confirmed of peace,
Between our Sovereign and the French King Charles,
Till term of eighteen months be full expired.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: Imprimis, It is agreed between the French King
Charles, and William de la Poule, Marquess of Suffolke, Ambassador for Henry King of England, that the said Henry shall wed
and espouse the Lady Margaret, daughter to Raynard King of
Naples, Cyssels, and Ierusalem, and crown her Queen of England, ere the 30 of the next month.
Item. It is further agreed between them, that the Duchess of Anioy and of Maine, shall be released and delivered over to the
King her fa.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How now uncle, whats the matter that you stay so suddenly.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: Pardon my Lord, a sudden qualm came over my heart,
Which dims mine eyes that I can read no more.
Uncle of Winchester, I pray you read on.

sp.speaker: Cardinall.
sp.l: Item, It is further agreed between them, that the
Duchess of Anioy and of Mayne, shall be released and delivered over to the King her father, and she sent over of the King
of Englands own proper cost and charges without dowry.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: They please us well, Lord Marquess kneel down, We
here create thee first Duke of Suffolke, and girt thee with the
sword. Cousin of Yorke, We here discharge your grace from
being Regent in the parts of France, till term of 18. months
be full expired.
Thanks uncle Winchester, Gloster, Yorke, and Buckingham, Somerset, Salsbury and Warwicke.
We thank you all for this great favour done,
In entertainment to my Princely Queen,
Come let us in, and with all speed provide
To see her Coronation be performed.

div2.stage: Exet King, Queene, and Suffolke, and Duke Humphrey staies all the rest.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: Brave Peers of England, Pillars of the state,
To you Duke Humphrey must unfold his grief,
What did my brother Henry toil himself,
And waste his subjects for to conquer France?
And did my brother Bedford spend his time
To keep in awe that stout unruly Realm?
And have not I and mine uncle Bewford here,
Done all we could to keep that land in peace?
And is all our labours then spent in vain,
For Suffolke he, the new made Duke that rules the roast,
Hath given away for our King Henries Queen,
The Duchess of Anioy and Mayne unto her father.
Ah Lords, fatal is this marriage cancelling our states,
Reversing Monuments of conquered France,
Undoing all, as none had never been done.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Why how now cousin Gloster, what needs this?
As if our King were bound unto your will,
And might not do his will without your leave,
Proud Protector, envy in thine eyes I see,
The big swollen venom of thy hateful heart,
That dares presume against that thy Sovereign likes.

sp.speaker: Humphr.
sp.l: Nay my Lord it is not my words that troubles you,
But my presence, proud Prelate as thou art:
But I will begone, and give thee leave to speak.
Farewell my Lords, and say when I am gone,
I prophesied France would be lost ere long.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: There goes our Protector in a rage,
My Lords you know he is my great enemy,
And though he be Protector of the land,
And thereby covers his deceitful thoughts,
For well you see, if he but walk the streets,
The common people swarm about him straight,
Crying Iesus bless your royal excellence,
With God preserve the good Duke Humphrey.
And many things besides that are not known,
Which time will bring to light in smooth Duke Humphrey.
But I will after him, and if I can
I will lay a plot to heave him from his seat.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: But let us watch this haughty Cardinal,
Cousin of Somerset be ruled by me,
We will watch Duke Humphrey and the Cardinal too,
And put them from the mark they fain would hit.

sp.speaker: Somerset.
sp.l: Thanks cousin Buckingham, join thou with me,
And both of us with the Duke of Suffolke,
We will quickly heave Duke Humphrey from his seat.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Content, Come then let us about it straight,
For either thou or I will be Protector.

sp.speaker: Salsb.
sp.l: Pride went before, Ambition follows after.
Whilst these do seek their own preferments thus,
My Lords let us seek for our Countries good,
Oft have I seen this haughty Cardinal
Swear, and forswear himself, and brave it out,
More like a Ruffian than a man of Church.
Cousin Yorke, the victories thou hast won,
In Ireland, Normandie, and in France,
Hath won thee immortal praise in England.
And thou brave Warwicke, my thrice valiant son,
Thy simple plainness and thy house-keeping,
Hath won thee credit amongst the common sort,
The reverence of mine age, and Neuels name,
Is of no little force if I command,
Then let us join all three in one for this,
That good Duke Humphrey may his state possess,
But wherefore weeps Warwicke my noble son.

sp.speaker: Warw.
sp.l: For grief that all is lost that Warwick won.
Sons. Anioy and Maine, both given away at once,
Why Warwick did win them, and must that then which we won
with our swords, be given away with words.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.p:
As I have read, our Kings of England were wont to
have large dowries with their wives, but our King Henry
gives away his own.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: Come sons away and look unto the maine.

sp.speaker: Warw.
sp.l: Unto the Maine, O father Maine is lost,
Which Warwicke by maine force did win from France,
Maine chance father you meant, but I meant Maine,
Which I will win from France, or else be slain.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Anioy and Maine, both given unto the French,
Cold news for me, for I had hope of France,
Even as I have of fertile England.
A day will come when Yorke shall claim his own,
And therefore I will take the Neuels parts,
And make a show of love to proud Duke Humphrey:
And when I spy advantage, claim the Crown,
For that is the golden mark I seek to hit:
Nor shall proud Lancaster usurp my right,
Nor hold the sceptre in his childish fist,
Nor wear the Diadem upon his head,
Whose church-like humours fits not for a Crown:
Then Yorke be still a while till time do serve,
Watch thou, and wake when others be asleep,
To pry into the secrets of the state,
Till Henry surfeiting in joys of love,
With his new bride, and Englands dear bought queen,
And Humphrey with the Peers be fallen at jars,
Then will I raise aloft the milk-white Rose,
With whose sweet smell the air shall be perfumed,
And in my Standard bear the Arms of Yorke,
To grapple with the House of Lancaster:
And force perforce, I will make him yield the Crown,
Whose bookish rule hath pulled fair England down.

div2.stage: Enter Duke Humphrey, and Dame Ellanor, Cobham his wife

sp.speaker: Elnor.
sp.l: Why droops my Lord like over ripened corn,
Hanging the head at Cearies plenteous load,
What seest thou Duke Humphrey King Henries Crown?
Reach at it, and if thine arm be too short,
Mine shall lengthen it. Art not thou a Prince,
Uncle to the King, and his Protector?
Then what shouldst thou lack that might content thy mind.

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: My lovely Nell, far be it from my heart,
To think of Treasons against my sovereign Lord,
But I was troubled with a dream tonight,
And God I pray, it do betide no ill.

sp.speaker: Elnor.
sp.l: What dreamt my Lord. Good Humphrey tell it me,
And I will interpret it, and when that is done,
I will tell thee then, what I did dream tonight.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: This night when I was laid in bed, I dreamt that
This my staff mine Office badge in Court,
Was broke in two, and on the ends were placed,
The heads of the Cardinal of Winchester,
And William de la Poule first Duke of Suffolke.

sp.speaker: Elnor.
sp.l: Tush my Lord, this signifies nought but this,
That he that breaks a stick of Glosters grove,
Shall for the offence, make forfeit of his head.
But now my Lord, I will tell you what I dreamt,
Methought I was in the Cathedral Church
At Westminster, and seated in the chair
Where Kings and Queens are crowned, and at my feet
Henry and Margaret with a Crown of gold
Stood ready to set it on my Princely head.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: Fie Nell. Ambitious woman as thou art,
Art thou not second woman in this land,
And the Protectors wife beloved of him,
And wilt thou still be hammering treason thus,
Away I say, and let me hear no more.

sp.speaker: Elnor.
sp.l: How now my Lord. What angry with your Nell,
For telling but her dream. The next I have
I will keep to myself, and not be rated thus.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: Nay Nell, I will give no credit to a dream,
But I would have thee to think on no such things.

sp.speaker: Messenger.
sp.p:
If it please your grace, the King and Queen
tomorrow morning will ride a-hawking to Saint Albones,
and craves your company along with them.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: With all my heart, I will attend his grace:
Come Nell, thou wilt go with us I am sure.

sp.speaker: Elnor.
sp.l: I will come after you, for I cannot go before,
But ere it be long, I will go before them all,
Despite of all that seek to cross me thus,
Who is within there?

sp.speaker: Elnor.
sp.l: What sir Iohn Hum, what news with you?

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.l: Iesus preserve your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Elnor.
sp.l: My Majesty. Why man I am but grace.

sp.speaker: Ser Iohn.
sp.l: Aye, but by the grace of God and Hums advise,
Your graces state shall be advanced ere long.

sp.speaker: Elnor.
sp.p:
What hast thou conferred with Margery Iordaine, the
cunning Witch of Ely, with Roger Bullingbrooke and the
rest, and will they undertake to do me good?

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p:
I have Madam, and they have promised me to raise
a Spirit from depth of under ground, that shall tell your
grace all questions you demand.

sp.speaker: Elnor.
sp.l: Thanks good sir Iohn. Some two days hence I guess
Will fit our time, then see that they be here:
For now the King is riding to Saint Albones,
And all the Dukes and Earls along with him,
When they be gone, then safely they may come,
And on the backside of my Orchard here,
There cast their Spells in silence of the night,
And so resolve us of the thing we wish,
Till when, drink that for my sake, And so farewell.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.l: Now sir Iohn Hum, No words but mum.
Seal up your lips, for you must silent be,
These gifts ere long will make me mighty rich,
The Duchess she thinks now that all is well,
But I have gold comes from another place,
From one that hired me to set her on,
To plot these Treasons against the King and Peers,
And that is the mighty Duke of Suffolke.
For he it is, but I must not say so,
That by my means must work the Duchess fall,
Who now by Conjurations thinks to rise.
But whist sir Iohn, no more of that I trow,
For fear you lose your head before you go.

div2.stage: Enter two Petitioners, and Peter the Armourers man.

sp.speaker: 1. Peti.
sp.l: Come sirs let us linger here abouts awhile,
Until my Lord Protector come this way,
That we may show his grace our several causes.

sp.speaker: 2. Peti.
sp.l: I pray God save the good Duke Humphries life,
For but for him a many were undone,
That cannot get no succour in the Court,
But see where he comes with the Queen.

div2.stage: Enter the Duke of Suffolke with the Queene, and they take him for Duke Humphrey, and giues him their writings.

sp.speaker: 1. Peti.
sp.l: O we are undone, this is the Duke of Suffolke.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Now good-fellows, whom would you speak withal?

sp.speaker: 2. Peti.
sp.l: If it please your Majesty, with my Lord Protectors
Grace.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Are your suits to his grace. Let us see them first,
Look on them my Lord of Suffolke.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: A complaint against the Cardinals man,
What hath he done?

sp.speaker: 2. Peti.
sp.l: Marry my Lord, he hath stole away my wife,
And they are gone together, and I know not where to find them.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: Hath he stole thy wife, that is some injury indeed.
But what say you?

sp.speaker: Peter Thump.
sp.p:
Marry sir I come to tell you that my master said,
that the Duke of Yorke was true heir unto the Crown, and
that the King was an usurer.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: An usurper thou wouldst say.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Aye forsooth an usurper.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Didst thou say the King was an usurper?

sp.speaker: Peter Thump.
sp.p:
No forsooth, I said my master said so, the other day
when we were scouring the Duke of Yorks Armour in our
garret.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: Aye marry this is something like,
Who is within there?

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: Sirrah take in this fellow and keep him close,
And send out a Pursuivant for his master straight,
We will hear more of this before the King.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: Now sir what yours? Let me see it,
Whats here?
A complaint against the Duke of Suffolke for enclosing the commons of long Melford.
How now sir knave.

sp.speaker: 1. Peti.
sp.l: I beseech your grace to pardon me, me, I am but a
Messenger for the whole town-ship.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: So now show your petitions to Duke Humphrey.
Villains get you gone and come not near the Court,
Dare these peasants write against me thus.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: My Lord of Suffolke, you may see by this,
The Commons loves unto that haughty Duke,
That seeks to him more than to King Henry:
Whose eyes are always poring on his book,
And never regards the honour of his name,
But still must be protected like a child,
And governed by that ambitious Duke,
That scarce will move his cap nor speak to us,
And his proud wife, high minded Elanor,
That ruffles it with such a troupe of Ladies,
As strangers in the Court takes her for the Queen.
The other day she vaunted to her maids,
That the very train of her worst gown,
Was worth more wealth than all my fathers lands,
Can any grief of mind be like to this.
I tell thee Poull, when thou didst run at Tilt,
And stolest away our Ladies hearts in France,
I thought King Henry had been like to thee,
Or else thou hadst not brought me out of France.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: Madam content yourself a little while,
As I was cause of your coming to England,
So will I in England work your full content:
And as for proud Duke Humphrey and his wife,
I have set lime-twigs that will entangle them,
As that your grace ere long shall understand.
But stay Madam, here comes the King.

div2.stage: Enter King Henry, and the Duke of Yorke and the Duke of Somerset on both sides of the King, whispering with him, and enter Duke Humphrey, Dame Elnor, the Duke of Buckingham, the Earle of Salsbury, the Earle of Warwicke, and the Cardinall of Winchester

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My Lords I care not who be Regent in France, or York,
or Somerset, all is one to me.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: My Lord, if Yorke have ill demeaned himself,
Let Somerset enjoy his place and go to France.

sp.speaker: Somerset.
sp.l: Then whom your grace think worthy, let him go,
And there be made the Regent over the French

sp.speaker: Warwicke.
sp.l: Whom soever you account worthy,
Yorke is the worthiest

sp.speaker: Cardinall.
sp.l: Peace Warwicke. Give thy betters leave to speak

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: The Cardinal is not my better in the field

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: All in this place are thy betters far

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: And Warwicke may live to be the best of all

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: My Lord in mine opinion, it were best that Somerset
were Regent over France

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: Madam our King is old enough himself,
To give his answer without your consent

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: If he be old enough, what needs your grace
To be Protector over him so long

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: Madam I am but Protector over the land,
And when it please his grace, I will resign my charge

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: Resign it then, for since that thou wast King,
As who is King but thee. The common state
Doth as we see, all wholly go to wrack,
And Millions of treasure hath been spent,
And as for the Regentship of France,
I say Somerset is more worthy than Yorke

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: I will tell thee Suffolke why I am not worthy,
Because I cannot flatter as thou canst

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: And yet the worthy deeds that York hath done,
Should make him worthy to be honoured here

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: Peace headstrong Warwicke

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Image of pride, wherefore should I peace?

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: Because here is a man accused of Treason,
Pray God the Duke of Yorke do clear himself
Ho, bring hither the Armourer and his man

div2.stage: Enter the Armourer and his man.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: If it please your grace, this fellow here, hath accused his master of
high Treason, And his words were these.
That the Duke of Yorke was lawful heir unto the Crown, and
that your grace was an usurper.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: I beseech your grace let him have what punishment the
the law will afford, for his villainy.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come hither fellow, didst thou speak these words?

sp.speaker: Armour.
sp.p:
If it shall please your Majesty, I never said any such
matter, God is my witness, I am falsely accused by this villain here.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: It is no matter for that, you did say so.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: I beseech your grace, let him have the law.

sp.speaker: Armour.
sp.p:
Alas my Lord, hang me if ever I spake the words,
my accuser is my prentice, and when I did correct him for his
fault the other day, he did vow upon his knees that he would
be even with me, I have good witness of this, and therefore
I beseech your Majesty do not cast away an honest man for
a villains accusation.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Uncle Gloster, what do you think of this?

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: The law my Lord is this by case, it rests suspicious,
That a day of combat be appointed,
And there to try each others right or wrong,
Which shall be on the thirtieth of this month,
With Ebony staves, and Standbags combating
In Smythfield, before your Royal Majesty.

sp.speaker: Armour.
sp.p: And I accept the Combat willingly.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Alas my Lord, I am not able to fight.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: You must either fight sirrah or else be hanged:
Go take them hence again to prison.

div2.stage: Exet with them. The Queene lets fall her gloue, and hits the Duches of Gloster, a boxe on the eare.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Give me my glove. Why Minion can you not see?

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: I cry you mercy Madam, I did mistake,
I did not think it had been you

sp.speaker: Elnor.
sp.l: Did you not proud French-woman,
Could I come near your dainty visage with my nails,
I would set my ten commandments in your face.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Be patient gentle Aunt.
It was against her will.

sp.speaker: Elnor.
sp.l: Against her will. Good King she will dandle thee,
If thou wilt always thus be ruled by her.
But let it rest. As sure as I do live,
She shall not strike dame Elnor unrevenged.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Believe me my love, thou wart much to blame,
I would not for a thousand pounds of gold,
My noble uncle had been here in place.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But see where he comes, I am glad he met her not.
Uncle Gloster, what answer makes your grace
Concerning our Regent for the Realm of France,
Whom thinks your grace is meetest for to send.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: My gracious Lord, then this is my resolve,
For that these words the Armourer should speak,
Doth breed suspicion on the part of Yorke,
Let Somerset be Regent over the French,
Till trials made, and Yorke may clear himself.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Then be it so my Lord of Somerset.
We make your grace Regent over the French,
And to defend our rights against foreign foes,
And so do good unto the Realm of France.
Make haste my Lord, it is time that you were gone,
The time of Truce I think is full expired.

sp.speaker: Somerset.
sp.l: I humbly thank your royal Majesty,
And take my leave to post with speed to France.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come uncle Gloster, now let us have our horse,
For we will to Saint Albones presently,
Madam your Hawk they say, is swift of flight,
And we will try how she will fly today.

div2.stage: Enter Elnor, with sir Iohn Hum, Koger Bullenbrooke a Coniurer, and Margery Iourdaine a Witch.

sp.speaker: Elnor.
sp.l: Here sir Iohn, take this scroll of paper here,
Wherein is writ the questions you shall ask,
And I will stand upon this Tower here,
And hear the spirit what it says to you,
And to my questions, write the answers down.

div2.stage: She goes vp to the Tower.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.l: Now sirs begin and cast your spells about,
And charm the fiends for to obey your wills,
And tell Dame Elnor of the thing she asks.

sp.speaker: Witch.
sp.l: Then Roger Bullinbrooke about thy task,
And frame a Circle here upon the earth,
Whilst I thereon all prostrate on my face,
Do talk and whisper with the devils below,
And conjure them for to obey my will.

div2.stage: She lies downe vpon her face. Bullenbrooke makes a Cirkle.

sp.speaker: Bullen.
sp.l: Dark Night, dread Night, the silence of the Night,
Wherein the Furies mask in hellish troupes,
Send up I charge you from Sosetus lake,
The spirit Askalon to come to me,
To pierce the bowels of this Centric earth,
And hither come in twinkling of an eye,
Askalon, Assenda, Assenda.

div2.stage: It thunders and lightens, and then the spirit riseth vp.

sp.speaker: Spirit.
sp.l: Now Bullenbrooke what wouldst thou have me do?

sp.speaker: Bullen.
sp.l: First of the King, what shall become of him?

sp.speaker: Spirit.
sp.l: The Duke yet lives that Henry shall depose,
But him out live, and die a violent death.

sp.speaker: Bullen.
sp.l: What fate await the Duke of Suffolke.

sp.speaker: Spirit.
sp.l: By water shall he die and take his end.

sp.speaker: Bullen.
sp.l: What shall betide the Duke of Somerset?

sp.speaker: Spirit.
sp.l: Let him shun Castles, safer shall he be upon the sandy
plains, than where Castles mounted stand.
Now question me no more, for I must hence again.

sp.speaker: Bullen.
sp.l: Then down I say, unto the damned poule
Where Pluto in his fiery Waggon sits.
Riding amidst the singed and parched smokes,
The Rode of Dytas by the River Stykes,
There howl and burn for ever in those flames,
Rise Iordaine rise, and stay thy charming Spells.
Sons, we are betrayed.

div2.stage: Enter the Duke of Yorke, and the Duke of Buckingham, and others.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Come sirs, lay hands on them, and bind them sure,
This time was well watched. What Madam are you there?
This will be great credit for your husband,
That your are plotting Treasons thus with Conjurers,
The King shall have notice of this thing.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: See here my Lord what the devil hath writ.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Give it me my Lord, I will show it to the King.
Go sirs, see them fast locked in prison.

sp.speaker: Bucking.
sp.l: My Lord, I pray you let me go post unto the King,
Unto S. Albones, to tell this news.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Content. Away then, about it straight.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Farewell my Lord.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Who*H62; is within there?

sp.speaker: One.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Sirrah, go will the Earls of Salsbury and Warwicke, to
sup with me tonight.

sp.speaker: One.
sp.p: I will my Lord.

div2.stage: Enter the King and Queene" with her Hawke on her fist, and Duke Humphrey and Suffolke, and the Cardinall, as if they came from hawking.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: My Lord, how did your grace like this last flight?
But as I cast her off the wind did rise,
And it was ten to one, old Ione had not gone out.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How wonderful the Lords works are on earth,
Even in these silly creatures of his hands,
Uncle Gloster, how hie your Hawk did sore?
And on a sudden soused the Partridge down.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: No marvel if it please your Majesty
My Lord Protectors Hawk done tower so well,
He knows his master loves to be aloft.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: Faith my Lord, it is but a base mind
That can sore no higher than a Falcon's pitch.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: I thought your grace would be above the clouds.

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: Aye my Lord Cardinal, were it not good
Your grace could flee to heaven.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Thy heaven is on earth, thy words and thoughts beat on
a Crown, proud Protector dangerous Peer, to smooth it thus
with King and common-wealth.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: How now my Lord, why this is more than needs,
Church-men so hot. Good uncle can you dote.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: Why not Having so good a quarrel and so bad a cause.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: As how, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: As you, my Lord. If it like your Lordly
Lords Protectorship.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: Why Suffolke, England knows thy insolence.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: And thy ambition Gloster.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Cease gentle Queen, and whet not on these furious
Lords to wrath, for blessed are the peace-makers on
earth.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Let me be blessed for the peace I make,
Against this proud Protector with my sword.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: Faith holy uncle, I would it were come to that,

sp.speaker: Cardinall.
sp.p: Even when thou darest.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p:
Dare. I tell thee Priest, Plantagenets could never
brooke the dare.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: I am Plantagenet as well as thou, and son to Iohn of
Gaunt.

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.p: In Bastardy.

sp.speaker: Cardin.
sp.p: I scorn thy words.

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.p:
Make up no factious numbers, but even in thine own
person meet me at the East end of the grove.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: Here is my hand, I will.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why how now Lords?

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p:
Faith Cousin Gloster, had not your man cast off so soon,
we had had more sport today, Come with thy sword
and buckler.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p: Faith Priest, I will shave your Crown.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: Protector, protect thyself well.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The wind grows high, so doth your choler Lords.

div2.stage: Enter one crying, A miracle, a miracle.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How now, now sirrah, what miracle is it?

sp.speaker: One.
sp.p:
If it please your grace, there is a man that came blind
to S. Albones, and hath received his sight at his shrine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Go fetch him hither, that we may glorify the Lord
with him.

div2.stage: Enter the Maior of Saint Albones and his brethren with Musicke, bearing the man that had bene blind, betweene two in a chaire.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou happy man, give God eternal praise,
For he it is, that thus hath helped thee

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: Where wast thou born?

sp.speaker: Poore man.
sp.l: At Barwicke sir, in the North

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: At Barwicke, and come thus far for help

sp.speaker: Poore man.
sp.l: Aye sir, it was told me in my sleep,
That sweet saint Albones, should give me my sight again

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: What art thou lame too?

sp.speaker: Poore man.
sp.l: Aye indeed sir, God help me

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: How camest thou lame?

sp.speaker: Poore man.
sp.l: With falling off on a plum-tree

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: Wart thou blind and wold clime plumtrees?

sp.speaker: Poore man.
sp.l: Never but once sir in all my life,
My wife did long for plums

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: But tell me, wart thou born blind?

sp.speaker: Poore man.
sp.l: Aye truly sir

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.l: Aye indeed sir, he was born blind

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: What art thou his mother?

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.l: His wife sir

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: Hadst thou been his mother,
Thou couldst have better told
Why let me see, I think thou canst not see yet

sp.speaker: Poore man.
sp.l: Yes truly master, as clear as day

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: Sayst thou so

sp.speaker: Poore man.
sp.l: Why red master, as red as blood

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: And his cloak?

sp.speaker: Poore man.
sp.l: Why that is green

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: And what colour is his hose?

sp.speaker: Poore man.
sp.l: Yellow master, yellow as gold

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: And what colour is my gown?

sp.speaker: Poore man.
sp.l: Black sir, as black as Jet

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Then belike he knows what colour Jet is on

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: And yet I think Jet did he never see

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: But cloaks and gowns ere this day many a
But tell me sirrah, what is my name? one

sp.speaker: Poore man.
sp.l: Alas master I know not

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: What is his name?

sp.speaker: Poore man.
sp.l: I know not

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: Nor his?

sp.speaker: Poore man.
sp.l: No truly sir

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: Nor his name?

sp.speaker: Poore man.
sp.l: No indeed master

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: What is thine own name?

sp.speaker: Poore man.
sp.l: Sander, if it please you master

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: Then Sander sit there, the lyingest knave in Christendom. If thou hadst been born blind, thou mightest as well have
known all our names, as thus to name the several colours we do
wear. Sight may distinguish of colours, but suddenly to nominate
them all, it is impossible. My Lords, saint Albones here hath done a
Miracle, and would you not think his cunning to be great, that
could restore this Cripple to his legs again

sp.speaker: Poore man.
sp.l: O master I would you could

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: My Masters of saint Albones,
Have you not Beadles in your Town,
And things called whips?

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.l: Yes my Lord, if it please your grace

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: Then send for one presently

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.l: Sirrah, go fetch the Beadle hither straight

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: Now fetch me a stool hither by and by.
Now sirrah, If you mean to save yourself from whipping,
Leap me over this stool and run away.

sp.speaker: Poore man.
sp.l: Alas master I am not able to stand alone,
You go about to torture me in vain.

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: Well sir, we must have you find your legs.
Sirrah Beadle, whip him till he leap over that same stool.

sp.speaker: Beadle.
sp.l: I will my Lord, come on sirrah, off with your doublet
quickly.

sp.speaker: Poore man.
sp.l: Alas master what shall I do, I am not able to stand.

div2.stage: After the Beadle hath hit him one girke, he leapes ouer the stoole and runnes away, and they run after him, crying, A miracle, a miracle.

sp.speaker: Hump.
sp.l: A miracle, a miracle, let him be taken again, and whipped
through every Market Town till he comes at Barwicke where he
was born.

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.l: It shall be done my Lord.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: My Lord Protector hath done wonders today,
He hath made the blind to see, and halt to go.

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: Aye but you did greater wonders, when you made whole
Dukedoms fly in a day.
Witness France.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Have done I say, and let me hear no more of that.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What news brings Duke Humprey of Buckingham?

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Ill news for some my Lord, and this it is,
That proud dame Elnor our Protectors wife,
Hath plotted Treasons against the King and Peers,
By witchcrafts, sorceries, and conjuring,
Who by such means did raise a spirit up,
To tell her what hap should betide the state,
But ere they had finished their devilish drift,
By Yorke and myself they were all surprised,
And here is the answer the devil did make to them.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: First of the King, what shall become of him?

sp.speaker: Reads.
sp.l: The Duke yet lives, that Henry shall depose,
Yet him out live, and die a violent death.
Gods will be done in all.
What fate awaits the Duke of Suffolke?
By water shall he die and take his end.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: By water must the Duke of Suffolke die?
It must be so, or else the devil doth lie.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let Somerset shun Castles,
For safer shall he be upon the sandy plains,
Than where Castles mounted stand.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Here is good stuff, how now my Lord Protector
This news I think hath turned your weapons point,
I am in doubt you will scarcely keep your promise.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: Forbear ambitious Prelate to urge my grief,
And pardon me my gracious Sovereign,
For here I swear unto your Majesty,
That I am guiltless of these heinous crimes
Which my ambitious wife hath falsely done,
And for she would betray her sovereign Lord,
I here renounce her from my bed and board,
And leave her open for the law to judge,
Unless she clear herself of this foul deed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come my Lords this night we will lodge in S. Albones,
And tomorrow we will ride to London,
And try the utmost of these Treasons forth,
Come uncle Gloster along with us,
My mind doth tell me thou art innocent.

div2.stage: Enter the Duke of Yorke, and the Earles of Salsbury and Warwicke.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: My Lords our simple supper ended, thus,
Let me reveal unto your honours here,
The right and title of the house of Yorke,
To Englands Crown by lineal descent.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Then Yorke begin, and if thy claim be good,
The Neuils are thy subjects to command.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Then thus my Lords.
Edward the third had seven sons,
The first was Edward the black Prince,
Prince of Wales.
The second was Edmund of Langly,
Duke of Yorke.
The third was Lyonell Duke of Clarence.
The fourth was Iohn of Gaunt,
The Duke of Lancaster.
The fifth was Roger Mortemor, Earle of March.
The sixth was sir Thomas of Woodstocke.
William of Winsore was the seventh and last.
Now, Edward the black Prince he died before his father, and left
behind him Richard, that afterwards was King, Crowned by
the name of Richard the second, and he died without an heir.
Edmund of Langly Duke of Yorke died, and left behind him two
daughters, Anne and Elinor.
Lyonell Duke of Clarence died, and left behind Alice, Anne,
and Elinor, that was after married to my father, and by her I
claim the Crown, as the true heir to Lyonell Duke
of Clarence, the third son to Edward the third. Now sir. In the
time of Richards reign, Henry of Bullingbrooke, son and heir
to Iohn of Gaunt, the Duke of Lancaster fourth son to Edward
the third, he claimed the Crown, deposed the Mirthful King, and
as both you know, in Pomphret Castle harmless Richard was
shamefully murthered, and so by Richards death came the house of
Lancaster unto the Crown.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: Saving your tale my Lord, as I have heard, in the reign
of Bullenbrooke, the Duke of Yorke did claim the Crown, and
but for Owin Glendor, had been King.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: True. But so it fortuned then, by means of that monstrous rebel Glendor, the noble Duke of York was done to death,
and so ever since the heirs of Iohn of Gaunt have possessed the
Crown. But if the issue of the elder should succeed before the issue of the younger, then am I lawful heir unto the kingdom.

sp.speaker: Warwicke.
sp.l: What plain proceedings can be more plain, he
claims it from Lyonel Duke of Clarence, the third son to Edward the third, and Henry from Iohn of Gaunt the fourth son.
So that till Lyonels issue fails, his should not reign. It fails not
yet, but flourisheth in thee and in thy sons, brave slips of such a stock.
Then noble father, kneel we both together, and in this private
place, be we the first to honour him with birthright to the Crown.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Long live Richard Englands royal King.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: I thank you both. But Lords I am not your King until
this sword be sheathed even in the heart blood of the house of Lancaster.

sp.speaker: Warwicke.
sp.l: Then Yorke advise thyself and take thy time,
Claim thou the Crown, and set thy standard up,
And in the same advance the milk-white Rose,
And then to guard it, will I rouse the Bear,
Environed with ten thousand Ragged-staves
To aid and help thee for to win thy right,
Maugre the proudest Lord of Henries blood,
That dares deny the right and claim of Yorke,
For why my mind presageth I shall live
To see the noble Duke of Yorke to be a King.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Thanks noble Warwicke, and Yorke doth hope to see,
The Earl of Warwicke live, to be the greatest man in England,
but the King. Come let us go.

div2.stage: Enter King Henry, and the Queene, Duke Humphrey, the Duke of Suffolke, and the Duke of Buckingham, the Cardinall, and Dame Elnor Cobham, led with the Officers, and then enter to them the Duke of Yorke, and the Earles of Salsbury and Warwicke.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Stand forth Dame Elnor Cobham Duchess of Gloster,
and hear the sentence pronounced against thee for these Treasons,
that thou hast committed against us, our States and Peers.
First for thy heinous crimes, thou shalt two days in London do
penance barefoot in the streets, with a white sheet about thy
body, and a wax Taper burning in thy hand. That done, thou
shalt be banished for ever into the Isle of Man, there to end thy
wretched days, and this is our sentence irrevocable. Away with
her.

sp.speaker: Elnor.
sp.l: Even to my death, for I have lived too long.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Grieve not noble uncle, but be thou glad,
In that these Treasons thus are come to light,
Lest God had poured his vengeance on thy head,
For her offences that thou heldest so dear.

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: O gracious Henry, give me leave awhile,
To leave your grace, and to depart away,
For sorrows tears hath gripped my aged heart,
And makes the fountains of mine eyes to swell,
And therefore good my Lord, let me depart.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: With all my heart good uncle, when you please,
Yet ere thou goest, Humphrey resign thy staff,
For Henry will be no more protected,
The Lord shall be my guide both for my land and me.

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: My staff, Aye noble Henry, my life and all,
My staff, I yield as willing to be thine,
As erst thy noble father made it mine,
And even as willing at thy feet I leave it,
As others would ambitiously receive it,
And long hereafter when I am dead and gone,
May honourable peace attend thy throne.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Uncle Gloster, stand up and go in peace,
No less beloved of us, than when
Thou wert Protector over my land.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Take up the staff, for here it ought to stand,
Where should it be, but in King Henries hand?

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Please it your Majesty, this is the day
That was appointed for the combating
Between the Armourer and his man, my Lord,
And they are ready when your grace doth please.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Then call them forth, that they may try their rights.

div2.stage: Enter at one doore the Armourer and his neighbours, drinking to him so much that he is drunken, and he enters with a drum before him, and his staffe with a sand-bag fastened to it, and at the other doore, his man with a drum and sand-bagge, and Prentises drinking to him.

sp.speaker: 1. Neighbor.
sp.l: Here neighbour Hornor, I drink to you in a cup of Sack.
And fear not neighbour, you shall do well enough.

sp.speaker: 2. Neigh.
sp.l: And here neighbour, here is a cup of Charneco.

sp.speaker: 3. Neigh.
sp.l: Here is a pot of good double beer, neighbour drink
And be merry, and fear not your man.

sp.speaker: Armourer.
sp.l: Let it come, i'faith I will pledge you all,
And a fig for Peter.

sp.speaker: 1. Prentise.
sp.l: Here Peter I drink to thee, and be not afeared.

sp.speaker: 2. Pren.
sp.l: Here Peter, here is a pint of Claret-wine for thee.

sp.speaker: 3. Pren.
sp.l: And here is a quart for me, and be merry Peter,
And fear not thy master, fight for credit of the Prentices.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: I thank you all, but I will drink no more,
Here Robin, and if I die, here I give thee my hammer,
And Will, thou shalt have my apron, and here Tom,
Take all the money that I have.
O Lord bless me, I pray God, for I am never able to deal with
my master, he hath learnt so much fence already.

sp.speaker: Salb.
sp.l: Come leave your drinking, and fall to blows.
Sirrah, what is thy name?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: Peter forsooth.

sp.speaker: Salbury.
sp.l: Peter, what more?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: Thump.

sp.speaker: Salsbury.
sp.l: Thump, then see that thou thump thy master.

sp.speaker: Armour.
sp.p:
Here is to thee neighbour, fill all the pots again, for before
we fight, look you, I will tell you my mind, for I am come
hither as it were of my man's instigation, to prove myself an honest
man, and Peter a knave, and so have at you Peter with down
right blows, as Bevies of South-hampton fell upon Askapart.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: Law you now, I told you he is in his fence already.

div2.stage: Alarmes, and Peter hits him on the head and fels him.

sp.speaker: Armour.
sp.p: Hold Peter, I confess, Treason, treason.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: O God I give thee praise.

sp.speaker: Pren.
sp.l: Ho well done Peter. God save the King.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Go take hence that Traitor from our sight,
For by his death we do perceive his guilt,
And God in justice hath revealed to us,
The truth and innocence of this poor fellow,
Which he had thought to have murthered wrongfully.
Come fellow, follow us for thy reward.

div2.stage: Enter Duke Humphrey and his men, in mourning cloakes.

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: Sirrah, what is oclock?

sp.speaker: Seruing.
sp.l: Almost ten my Lord.

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: Then is that woeful hour hard at hand,
That my poor Lady should come by this way,
In shameful penance wandering in the streets,
Sweet Nell, ill can thy noble mind abrook,
The abject people gazing on thy face,
With envious looks laughing at thy shame,
That erst did follow thy proud Chariot wheels,
When thou didst ride in triumph through the streets.

div2.stage: Enter Dame Elnor Cobham bare-foote, and a white sheete about her, with a waxe candle in her hand, and verses written on her backe and pind on, and accompanied with the Sheriffes of London, and Sir Iohn Standly, and Officers, with billes and holbards.

sp.speaker: Seruing.
sp.l: My gracious Lord, see where my Lady comes,
Please it your grace, we will take her from the Sheriffs?

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: I charge you for your lives stir not a foot,
Nor offer once to draw a weapon here,
But let them do their office as they should.

sp.speaker: Elnor.
sp.l: Come you my Lord to see my open shame?
Ah Gloster, now thou doest penance too,
See how the giddy people look at thee,
Shaking their heads, and pointing at thee here,
Go get thee gone, and hide thee from their sights,
And in thy pent up study rue my shame,
And ban thine enemies. Ah mine and thine.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Ah Nell, sweet Nell, forget this extreme grief,
And bear it patiently to ease thy heart.

sp.speaker: Elnor.
sp.l: Ah Gloster teach me to forget myself,
For whilst I think I am thy wedded wife,
Then thought of this, doth kill my woeful heart.
The ruthless flints do cut my tender feet,
And when I start the cruel people laugh,
And bids me be advised how I tread,
And thus with burning Taper in my hand,
Mauled up in shame with papers on my back,
Ah, Gloster, can I endure this and live.
Sometime I will say I am Duke Humphreys wife,
And he a Prince, Protector of the land,
But so he ruled, and such a Prince he was,
As he stood by, whilst I his forlorn Duchess
Was led with shame, and made a laughing stock,
To every idle rascaled follower.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: My lovely Nell, what wouldst thou have me do?
Should I attempt to rescue thee from hence,
I should incur the danger of the law,
And thy disgrace would not be shadowed so.

sp.speaker: Elnor.
sp.l: Be thou mild, and stir not at my disgrace,
Until the axe of death hang over thy head,
As shortly sure it will. For Suffolke he,
The new made Duke, that may do all in all
With her that loves him so, and hates us all,
And impious Yorke and Bewford that false Priest,
Have all limed bushes to betray thy wings,
And fly thou how thou can they will entangle thee.

sp.speaker: Herald.
sp.p:
I summon your Grace, unto his highness Parliament
holden at saint Edmunds-Bury, the first of the next month.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: A Parliament and our consent never craved
Therein before. This is sudden.
Well, we will be there.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: Master Sheriff, I pray proceed no further against my
Lady, than the course of law extends.

sp.speaker: Sheriffe.
sp.l: Please it your grace, my office here doth end,
And I must deliver her to sir Iohn Standly,
To be conducted into the Isle of Man.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.l: Must you sir Iohn conduct my Lady?

sp.speaker: Standly.
sp.l: Aye my gracious Lord, for so it is decreed,
And I am so commanded by the King.

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: I pray you sir Iohn, use her near the worse,
In that I entreat you to use her well.
The world may smile again and I may live,
To do you favour if you do it her,
And so sir Iohn farewell.

sp.speaker: Elnor.
sp.l: What gone my Lord, and bid not me farewell.

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: Witness my bleeding heart, I cannot stay to speak.

sp.speaker: Elnor.
sp.l: Then is he gone, is noble Closter gone,
And doth Duke Humphrey now forsake me too?
Then let me haste from out fair Englands bounds,
Come Standly come, and let us haste away.

sp.speaker: Standly.
sp.l: Madam let us go unto some house hereby,
Where you may shift yourself before we go.

sp.speaker: Elnor.
sp.l: Ah good sir Iohn, my shame cannot be hid,
Nor put away with casting off my sheet:
But come let us go, master Sheriff farewell,
Thou hast but done thy office as thou shouldst.

div2.stage: Enter to the Parlament. Enter two Heralds before, then the Duke of Buckingham, and the Duke of Suffolke, and then the Duke of Yorke, and the Cardinall of Winchester, and then the King and the Queene, and then the Earle of Salisbury, and the Earle of Warwicke.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I wonder our uncle Gloster stays so long.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Can you not see, or will you not perceive,
How that ambitious Duke doth use himself?
The time hath been, but now that time is past,
That none so humble as Duke Humphrey was:
But now let one meet him even in the morn,
When everyone will give the time of day,
And he will neither move nor speak to us.
See you not how the Commons follow him
In troupes, crying, God save the good Duke Humphrey,
And with long life, Iesus preserve his grace,
Honouring him as if he were their King.
Gloster is no little man in England,
And if he list to stir commotions,
It is likely that the people will follow him.
My Lord, if you imagine there is no such thing,
Then let it pass, and call it a woman's fear.
My Lord of Suffolke, Buckingham, and Yorke,
Disprove my Allegations if you can,
And by your speeches, if you can reprove me,
I will subscribe and say, I wronged the Duke.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: Well hath your grace foreseen into that Duke,
And if I had been licensed first to speak,
I think I should have told your graces tale.
Smooth runs the brooke whereas the stream is deepest.
No, no, my sovereign, Gloster is a man
Unsounded yet, and full of deep deceit.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Welcome Lord Somerset, what news from France?

sp.speaker: Somer.
sp.l: Cold news my Lord, and this it is,
That all your holds and Towns within those Territories
Is overcome my Lord, all is lost.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Cold news indeed Lord Somerset,
But Gods will be done.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Cold news for me, for I had hope of France,
Even as I have of fertile England.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Pardon my liege, that I have staid so long

sp.speaker: Suffol.
sp.l: Nay, Gloster know, that thou art come too soon,
Unless thou prove more loyal than thou art,
We do arrest thee on high treason here

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: Why Suffolkes Duke thou shalt not see me blush
Nor change my countenance for thine arrest,
Whereof am I guilty, who are my accusers?

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: It is thought my lord, your grace took bribes from France,
And stopped the soldiers of their pay,
By which his Majesty hath lost all France

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: Is it but thought so, and who are they that think so?
So God help me, as I have watched the night
Ever intending good for England still,
That penny that ever I took from France,
Be brought against me at the judgment day
I never robbed the soldiers of their pay,
Many a pound of mine own proper cost
Have I sent over for the soldiers wants,
Because I would not rack the needy Commons

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: In your Protectorship you did devise
Strange torments for offenders, by which means
England hath been defamed by tyranny

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Why it is well known that whilst I was protector
Pity was all the fault that was in me,
A murtherer or foul felonious thief,
That robs and murthers silly passengers,
I tortured above the rate of common law

sp.speaker: Suffolk.
sp.l: Tush my Lord, these be things of no account,
But greater matters are laid unto your charge,
I do arrest thee on high treason here,
And commit thee to my good Lord Cardinal,
Until such time as thou canst clear thyself

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Good uncle obey to his arrest,
I have no doubt but thou shalt clear thyself,
My conscience tells me thou art innocent

sp.speaker: Hump.
sp.l: Ah gracious Henry these days are dangerous,
And would my death might end these miseries,
And stay their moods for good King Henries sake,
But I am made the Prologue to their play,
And thousands more must follow after me,
That dreads not yet their lives destruction
Suffolkes hateful tongue blabs his hearts malice,
Bewfords fiery eyes shows his envious mind,
Buckinghams proud looks bewrays his cruel thoughts,
And dogged Yorke that levels at the Moon
Whose overweening arm I have held back
All you have joined to betray me thus:
And you my gracious Lady and sovereign mistress,
Causeless have laid complaints upon my head,
I shall not want false witnesses enough,
That so amongst you, you may have my life
The Proverb no doubt will be well performed,
A staff is quickly found to beat a dog

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: Doth he not twit our sovereign Lady here,
As if that7H3; she with ignominies wrong,
Had suborned or hired some to swear against his life

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Aye but I can give the loser leave to speak

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: Far truer spoke than meant, I loose indeed,
Beshrew the winners hearts, they play me false

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: He will wrest the sense and keep us here all day,
My Lord of Winchester, see him sent away

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Who is within there? Take in Duke Humphrey,
And see him guarded sure within my house

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: O! thus King Henry casts away his crouch,
Before his legs can bear his body up,
And puts his watchful shepherd from his side,
Whilst wolves stand snaring who shall bite him first
Farewell my sovereign, long mayest thou enjoy,
Thy fathers happy days free from annoy

div2.stage: Exet Humphrey, with the Cardinals men

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My Lords what to your wisdoms shall seem best,
Do and undo as if ourself were here

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: What will your highness leave the Parliament?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Aye Margaret. My heart is killed with grief,
Where I may sit and sigh in endless moan,
For who is a Traitor, Gloster he is none

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Then sit we down again my Lord Cardinal,
Suffolke, Buckingham, Yorke, and Somerset
Let us consult of proud Duke Humphries fall
In mine opinion it were good he died,
For safety of our King and Common-wealth

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: And so think I Madam, for as you know,
If our King Henry had shook hands with death,
Duke Humphrey then would look to be our King:
And it may be by policy he works,
To bring to pass the thing which now we doubt,
The Fox barks not when he would steal the Lamb,
But if we take him ere he do the deed,
We should not question if that he should live
No. Let him die, in that he is a Fox,
Lest that in living he offend us more

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Then let him die before the Commons know,
For fear that they do rise in Arms for him

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Then do it suddenly my Lords

sp.speaker: Suffol.
sp.l: Let that be my Lord Cardinals charge and mine

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Agreed, for he is already kept within my house

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: How now sirrah, what news?

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.l: Madam I bring you news from Ireland,
The wild O'neill my Lords, is up in Arms,
With troupes of Irish Kerns that uncontrolled,
Doth plant themselves within the English pale

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: What redress shall we have for this my Lords?

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: It were very good that my Lord of Somerset
That fortunate Champion were sent over,
And burns and spoils the Country as they go
To keep in awe the stubborn Irishmen,
He did so much good when he was in France

sp.speaker: Somer.
sp.l: Had Yorke been there with all his far fetched
Policies, he might have lost as much as I

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Aye, for Yorke would have lost his life before
That France should have revolted from Englands rule

sp.speaker: Somer.
sp.l: Aye so thou mightst, and yet have governed worse than I

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: What worse than nought, then a shame take all

sp.speaker: Somer.
sp.l: Shame on thyself, that wisheth shame

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Somerset forbear, good Yorke be patient,
And do thou take in hand to cross the seas,
With troupes of Armed men to quell the pride
Of those ambitious Irish that rebel

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Well Madam sith your grace is so content,
Let me have some bands of chosen soldiers,
And Yorke shall try his fortune against those kerns

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Yorke thou shalt. My Lord of Buckingham,
Let it be your charge to muster up such soldiers
As shall suffice him in these needful wars

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Madam I will, and levy such a band
As soon shall overcome those Irish Rebels,
But Yorke, where shall those soldiers stay for thee?

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: At Bristow, I will expect them ten days hence

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: Then thither shall they come, and so farewell

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Adieu my Lord of Buckingham

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Suffolke remember what you have to do
And you Lord Cardinal concerning Duke Humphrey,
It were good that you did see to it in time,
Come let us go, that it may be performed

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: Now York bethink thyself and rouse thee up,
Take time whilst it is offered thee so fair,
Lest when thou wouldst, thou canst it not attain,
It was men I lacked, and now they give them me,
And now whilst I am busy in Ireland,
I have seduced a headstrong Kentishman,
Iohn Cade of Ashford,
Under the title of Iohn Mortemer,
To raise commotion, and by that means
I shall perceive how the common people
Do affect the claim and house of Yorke,
Then if he have success in his affairs,
From Ireland then comes Yorke again,
To reap the harvest which that coistrel sowed,
Now if he should be taken and condemned,
He will never confess that I did set him on,
And therefore ere I go I will send him word,
To put in practise and to gather head,
That so soon as I am gone he may begin
To rise in Arms with troupes of country swains,
To help him to perform this enterprise
And then Duke Humphrey, he well made away,
None then can stop the light to Englands Crown,
But Yorke can tame and headlong pull them down

div2.stage: Then the Curtaines being drawne, Duke Humphrey is discouered in his bed, and two men lying on his brest and smothering him in his bed. And then enter the Duke of Suffolke to them.

sp.speaker: Suffolk.
sp.l: How now sirs, what have you dispatched him?

sp.speaker: One.
sp.l: Aye my Lord, he is dead I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: Then see the clothes laid smooth about him still,
That when the King comes, he may perceive
No other, but that he died of his own accord
All things is handsome now my Lord.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: Then draw the Curtains again and get you gone,
And you shall have your firm reward anon.

div2.stage: Exet murtherers. Then enter the King and Queene, the Duke of Buckingham, and the Duke of Somerset, and the Cardinall.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My Lord of Suffolke go call our uncle Gloster,
Tell him this day we will that he do clear himself.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: I will my Lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And good my Lords proceed no further against our uncle Gloster,
Then by just proof you can affirm,
For as the sucking child or harmless lamb,
So is he innocent of treason to our state.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How now Suffolke, where is our uncle?

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: Dead in his bed, my Lord Gloster is dead.

div2.stage: The King falles in a sound.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Ay-me, the King is dead: help, help, my Lords.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: Comfort my Lord, gracious Henry comfort.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: What doth my Lord of Suffolk bid me comfort?
Came he even now to sing a Ravens note,
And thinks he that the chirping of a Wren,
By crying comfort through a hollow voice,
Can satisfy my griefs, or ease my heart:
Thou baleful messenger out of my sight,
For even in thine eyeballs murther sits,
Yet do not go. Come Basilisk
And kill the silly gazer with thy looks.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Why do you rate my Lord of Suffolke thus,
As if that he had caused Duke Humphreys death?
The Duke and I too, you know were enemies,
And you had best say that I did murther him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ah woe is me, for wretched Glosters death.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Be woe for me more wretched than he was,
What doest thou turn away and hide thy face?
I am no loathsome leper look on me,
Was I for this nigh wracked upon the sea,
And thrice by awkward winds driven back from Englands bounds,
What might it bode, but that well foretelling
Winds, said, seek not a scorpions nest.

div2.stage: Enter the Earles of Warwicke and Salisbury.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: My Lord, the Commons like an angry hive of bees,
Run up and down, caring not whom they sting,
For good Duke Humphreys death, whom they report
To be murthered by Suffolke and the Cardinal here.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: That he is dead good Warwick, is too true,
But how he died God knows, not Henry.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Enter his priuie chamber my Lord and view the body.
Good father stay you with the rude multitude, till I return.

sp.speaker: Salb.
sp.l: I will son.

div2.stage: Exet Salbury. Warwicke drawes the curtaines and showes Duke Humphrey in his bed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ah uncle Gloster, heaven receive thy soul.
Farewell poor Henries joy, now thou art gone.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Now by his soul that took our shape upon him,
To free us from his fathers dreadful curse,
I am resolved that violent hands were laid,
Upon the life of this thrice famous Duke.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: A dreadful oath sworn with a solemn tongue,
What instance gives Lord Warwicke for these words?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Oft have I seen a timely parted ghost,
Of ashy semblance, pale and bloodless,
But lo the blood is settled in his face,
More better coloured than when he lived,
His well proportioned beard made rough and stern,
His fingers spread abroad as one that grasped for life,
Yet was by strength surprised, the least of these are probable,
It cannot choose but he was murthered.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Suffolke and the Cardinal had him in charge,
And they I trust sir, are no murtherers.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Aye, but it was well known they were not his friends,
And it is well seen he found some enemies.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: But have you no greater proofs then these?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Who sees a heifer dead and bleeding fresh,
And sees hard-by a butcher with an axe,
But will suspect it was he that made the slaughter?
Who finds the partridge in the puttocks nest,
But will imagine how the bird came there,
Although the kite soar with unbloody beak?
Even so suspicious is this Tragedy.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Are you the kite Bewford, where is your talants?
Is Suffolke the butcher, where is his knife?

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: I wear no knife to slaughter sleeping men,
But here is a vengeful sword rusted with case,
That shall be scoured in his rancorous heart,
That slanders me with murthers crimson badge,
Say if thou dare, proud Lord of Warwickshire,
That I am guilty in Duke Humphreys death.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: What dares not Warwicke, if false Suffolke dare him?

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: He dares not calm his contumelious spirit,
Nor cease to be an arrogant controller,
Though Suffolk dare him twenty hundredth times.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Madam be still, with reverence may I say it,
That every word you speak in his defence,
Is slander to your royal Majesty.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: Blunt witted Lord, ignoble in thy words,
If ever Lady wronged her Lord so much,
Thy mother took unto her blameful bed,
Some stern untutored churl, and noble stock
Was graft with crabtree slip, whose fruit thou art,
And never of the Neuels noble race.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: But that the guilt of murther bucklers thee,
And I should rob the deaths man of his fee,
Quitting thee thereby of ten thousand shames,
And that my sovereigns presence makes me mute,
I would false murtherous coward on thy knees
Make thee crave pardon for thy passed speech,
And say it was thy mother that thou meant-est,
That thou thyself was born in bastardy,
And after all this fearful homage done,
Give thee thy hire and send thy soul to hell,
Pernicious blood-sucker of sleeping men.

sp.speaker: Suffol.
sp.l: Thou shouldst be waking whilst I shed thy blood,
If from this presence thou dare go with me.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Away even now, or I will drag thee hence.

div2.stage: Warwicke puls him out. Exet Warwicke and Suffolke, and then all the Commons within, cries, downe with Suffolke, downe with Suffolk. And then enter againe, the Duke of Suffolke and Warwicke, with their weapons drawne.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why how now Lords?

sp.speaker: Suf.
sp.l: The Traitorous Warwicke with the men of Berry,
Set all upon me mighty sovereign i

div2.stage: The Commons againe cries, downe with Suffolke downe with Suffolke. And then enter from them, the Earle of Salbury.

sp.speaker: Salb.
sp.l: My Lord, the Commons sends you word by me,
That unless false Suffolke here be done to death,
Or banished fair Englands Territories,
That they will err from your highness person,
They say by him the good Duke Humphrey died,
They say by him they fear the ruin of the realm.
And therefore if you love your subjects weal,
They wish you to banish him from forth the land.

sp.speaker: Suf.
sp.l: Indeed it is like the Commons rude unpolished hinds
Would send such message to their sovereign,
But you my Lord were glad to be employed,
To try how quaint an Orator you were,
But all the honour Salsbury hath got,
Is, that he was the Lord Ambassador
Sent from a sort of Tinkers to the King.

div2.stage: The Commons cries, an answere from the King, my Lord of Salsbury.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Good Salsbury go back again to them,
Tell them we thank them all for their loving care,
And had I not been cited thus by their means,
Myself had done it. Therefore here I swear,
If Suffolke be found to breathe in any place,
Where I have rule, but three days more, he dies.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: O Henry, reverse the doom of gentle Suffolkes banishment.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ungentle Queen to call him gentle Suffolke,
Speak not for him, for in England he shall not rest,
If I say, I may relent, but if I swear, it is irrevocable.
Come good Warwicke and go thou in with me,
For I have great matters to impart to thee.

div2.stage: Exet King and Warwicke, Manet Queene and Suffolke.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Hell fire and vengeance go along with you,
There is two of you, the devil make the third,
Fie womanish man, canst thou not curse thy enemies?

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: A plague upon them, wherefore should I curse them?
Could curses kill as do the Mandrakes groans,
I would invent as many bitter terms
Delivered strongly through my fixed teeth,
With twice so many signs of deadly hate,
As leave fast envy in her loathsome cave,
My tongue should stumble in mine earnest words,
Mine eyes should sparkle like the beaten flint,
My hair be fixed on end, as one distraught,
And every joint should seem to curse and ban,
And now methinks my burthened heart would break,
Should I not curse them. Poison be their drink,
Gall worse than gall, the daintiest thing they taste.
Their sweetest shade a grove of cypress trees.
Their softest touch as smart as lizards stings.
Their music frightful, like the serpents hiss.
And boding screech-owls make the consort full.
All the foul terrors in dark seated hell.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Enough sweet Suffolke, thou torments thyself.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: You bad me ban, and will you bid me seize?
Now by this ground that I am banished from,
Well could I curse away a winters night,
And standing naked on a mountain top,
Where biting cold would never let grass grow,
And think it but a minute spent in sport.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: No more. Sweet Suffolke hie thee hence to France,
Or live where thou wilt within this worlds globe,
I will have an Irish that shall find thee out,
And long thou shalt not stay, but I will have thee repealed,
Or venture to be banished myself.
O let this kiss be printed in thy hand,
That when thou seest it, thou mayest think on me.
Away, I say, that I may feele my grief,
For it is nothing whilst thou standest here.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: Thus is poor Suffolke ten times banished,
Once by the King, but three times thrice by thee.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: How now, whither goes Vawse so fast?

sp.speaker: Vawse.
sp.l: To signify unto his Majesty,
That Cardinal Bewford is at point of death,
Sometimes he raves and cries as he were mad,
Sometimes he calls upon Duke Humphries Ghost,
And whispers to his pillow as to him,
And sometime he calls to speak unto the King,
And I am going to certify unto his grace,
That even now he called aloud for him.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Go then good Vawse and certify the King.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: O what is worldly pomp, all men must die,
And woe am I for Bewfords heavy end,
But why mourn I for him, whilst thou art here?
Sweet Suffolke hie thee hence to France,
For if the King do come, thou sure must die.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: And if I go I cannot live: but here to die,
What were it else, but like a pleasant slumber
In thy lap?
Here could I, could I, breath my soul into the air,
As mild and gentle as the new born babe,
That dies with mothers dug between his lips,
Where from thy sight I should be raging mad,
And call for thee to close mine eyes,
Or with thy lips to stop my dying soul,
That I might breathe it so into thy body,
And then it lived in sweet Elyziam,
By thee to die, were but to die in jest,
From thee to die, were torment more than death,
O let me stay, befall, what may befall.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: O mightst thou stay with safety of thy life,
Then shouldst thou stay, but heavens deny it,
And therefore go, but hope ere long to be repealed.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: I go.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: And take my heart with thee.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: A jewel locked into the woefullest cask,
That ever yet contained a thing of worth,
Thus like a splitted bark so sunder we.
This way fall I to death.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: This way for me.

div2.stage: Enter King and Salsbury, and then the Curtaines be drawne, and the Cardinall is discouered in his bed, rauing and staring as if he were madde.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: O death, if thou wilt let me live but one whole year,
I will give thee as much gold as will purchase such another Island.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O see my Lord of Salsbury how he is troubled,
Lord Cardinal, remember Christ must save thy soul.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Why died he not in his bed?
What would you have me to do then?
Can I make men live whether they will or no?
Sirrah, go fetch me the strong poison which the Apothecary sent me.
O see where duke Humphreys ghost doth stand,
And stares me in the face. Look, look, comb down his hair,
So now he is gone again: O, O, O.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: See how the pangs of death doth gripe his heart.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Lord Cardinal, if thou diest assured of heavenly bliss,
Hold up thy hand and make some sign to us.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O see he dies, and makes no sign at all.
O God forgive his soul.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: So bad an end did never none behold,
But as his death, so was his life in all.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Forbear to judge, good Salsbury forbear,
For God will judge us all.
Go take him hence, and see his funerals be performed.

div2.stage: Alarmes within, and the chambers be discharged, like as it were a fight at sea. And then enter the Captaine of the ship and the Maister, and the Maisters Mate, and the Duke of Suffolk disguised, and others with him, and Water Whickmore.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Bring forward these prisoners that scorned to yield,
Unlade their goods with speed and sink their ship,
Here Master, this prisoner I give to you.
This other, the Master's Mate shall have,
And Water Whickmore thou shalt have this man,
And let them pay their ransoms ere they pass.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: Water!

sp.speaker: Water.
sp.l: How now, what doest fear me?
Thou shalt have better cause anon.

sp.speaker: Suf.
sp.l: It is thy name affrights me, not thy self.
I do remember well, a cunning Wizard told me,
That by Water I should die:
Yet let not that make thee bloody minded.
Thy name being rightly sounded,
Is Gualter, not Water.

sp.speaker: Water.
sp.l: I lost mine eye in boarding of the ship,
And therefore ere I merchant-like sell blood for gold,
Then cast me headlong down into the sea.

sp.speaker: 2. Priso.
sp.l: But what shall our ransoms be?

sp.speaker: Mai.
sp.l: A hundredth pounds a piece, either pay that or die.

sp.speaker: 2. Priso.
sp.l: Then save our lives, it shall be paid.

sp.speaker: Water.
sp.l: Come sirrah, thy life shall be the ransom
I will have.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: Stay villain, thy prisoner is a Prince,
The Duke of Suffolke, William de la Poull.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: The Duke of Suffolke folded up in rags.

sp.speaker: Suf.
sp.l: Aye sir, but these rags are no part of the Duke,
Ioue sometime went disguised, and why not I?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Aye but Ioue was never slain as thou shalt be.

sp.speaker: Suf.
sp.l: Base Jady groom, King Henries blood
The honourable blood of Lancaster,
Cannot be shed by such a lowly swain,
I am sent Ambassador for the Queen to France,
I charge thee waft me cross the channel safe.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I will waft thee to thy death, go Water take him hence,
And on our long boats side, chop off his head.

sp.speaker: Suf.
sp.l: Thou darest not for thine own.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Yes Poull.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: Poull.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Aye Poull, puddle kennel, sink and dirt,
I will stop that yawning mouth of thine,
Those lips of thine that so oft have kissed the
Queen, shall sweep the ground, and thou that
Smiledest at good Duke Humphreys death,
Shalt live no longer to infect the earth.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: This villain being but Captain of a Pinnais,
Threatens more plagues than mighty Abradas,
The great Masadonian Pirate,
Thy words adds fury and not remorse in me.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Aye but my deeds shall stay thy fury soon.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: Hast not thou waited at my Trencher,
When we have feasted with Queen Margret?
Hast not thou kissed thy hand and held my stirrup?
And bareheaded plodded by my foot-cloth Mule,
And thought thee happy when I smiled on thee?
This hand hath writ in thy defence,
Then shall I charm thee, hold thy lavish tongue.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Away with him Water, I say, and off with his head.

sp.speaker: 1. Priso.
sp.l: Good my Lord, entreat him mildly for your life.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: First let this neck stoop to the axes edge,
Before this knee do bow to any,
Save to the God of heaven and to my King:
Suffolkes imperial tongue cannot plead
To such a Jady groom.

sp.speaker: Water.
sp.l: Come, come, why do we let him speak,
I long to have his head for ransom of mine eye.

sp.speaker: Suffolk.
sp.l: A Swordar and bandeto slave,
Murthered sweet Tully.
Brutus bastard-hand stabbed Iulius Caesar,
And Suffolke dies by Pirates on the seas.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Off with his head, and send it to the Queen,
And ransomless this prisoner shall go free,
To see it safe delivered unto her.
Come let us go.

div2.stage: Enter two of the Rebels with long staues.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p:
Come away Nick, and put a long staff in thy pike, and
provide thyself, for I Can tell thee, they have been up this two
days.

sp.speaker: Nicke.
sp.p:
Then they had more need to go to bed now,
But sirrah George what is the matter?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p:
Why sirrah, Iack Cade the Diar of Ashford here,
He means to turn this land, and set a new nap on it.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p:
Aye marry he had need so, for it is grown threadbare,
It was never merry world with us, since these gentle men came up.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I warrant thee, thou shalt never see a Lord wear a leather apron now adays.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: But sirrah, who comes more beside Iacke Cade?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p:
Why there is Dicke the Butcher, and Robin the Saddler,
and Will that came a wooing to our Nan last Sunday, and Harry
and Tom, and Gregory that should have your Parnill, and a great
sort more is come from Rochester, and from Maydstone, and Canterbury,
and all the Towns here abouts, and we must all be Lords
or squires, as soon as Iacke Cade is King.

sp.speaker: Nicke.
sp.p: Hark, hark, I hear the Drum, they be coming.

div2.stage: Enter Iacke Cade, Dicke Butcher, Robin, Will, Tom, Harry and the rest, with long staues.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.p: Proclaim silence.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Silence.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.p: I Iohn Cade so named for my valiancy.

sp.speaker: Dicke.
sp.p: Or rather for stealing of a Cade of Sprats.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.p: My father was a Mortemer.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: He was an honest man and a good Bricklayer.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.p: My mother came of the Brasses.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: She was a Peddlers daughter indeed, and sold many laces.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: And now being not able to occupy her furred pack,
She washeth bucks up and down the country.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.p: Therefore I am honourably born.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.l: Aye for the field is honourable, for he was born
Under a hedge, for his father had no house but the Cage.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.p: I am able to endure much.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: That is true, I know he can endure anything,
For I have seen him whipped two market days together.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.p: I fear neither sword nor fire.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: He need not fear the sword, for his coat is of proof.

sp.speaker: Dicke.
sp.p:
But methinks he should fear the fire, being so often
burnt in the hand, for stealing of sheep.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.p:
Therefore be brave, for your Captain is brave, and vows
reformation: you shall have seven half-penny loaves for a penny,
and the three hooped pot, shall have ten hoops, and it shall be felony
to drink small beer, and if I be king, as king I will be.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: God save your majesty.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.p:
I thank you good people, you shall all eat and drink of
my score, and go all in my livery, and we will have no writing, but
the score and the Tally, and there shall be no laws but such as comes
from my mouth.

sp.speaker: Dicke.
sp.p:
We shall have sore laws then, for he was thrust into the
mouth the other day.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p:
Aye and stinking law too, for his breath stinks so, that one
cannot abide it.

div2.stage: Enter Will with the Clarke of Chattam.
