sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: O Captain a prize.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.p: Whose that Will?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p:
The Clarke of Chattam, he can write and read and cast
account, I took him setting of boys copies, and he has a book
in his pocket with red letters.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Sons, he is a conjurer bring him hither.
Now sir, what is your name?

sp.speaker: Clarke.
sp.l: Emanuell sir, if it shall please you.

sp.speaker: Dicke.
sp.l: It will go hard with you, I can tell you,
For they use to write that oath top of letters.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: And what do you use to write your name?
Or do you as ancient forefathers have done,
Use the score and the Tally?

sp.speaker: Clarke.
sp.p:
Nay, true sir, I praise God I have been so well brought
up, that I can write mine own name.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.p:
O he has confessed, go hang him with his penny-inkhorn
about his neck.

div2.stage: Exet one with the Clarke. Enter Tom.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
Captain. News, news, sir Humphrey Stafford and his
brother are coming with the kings power, and mean to kill us all.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.p: Let them come, he is but a knight is he?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: No, no, he is but a knight.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Why then to equal him, I will make myself knight.
Kneel down Iohn Mortemer,
Rise up sir Iohn Mortemer.
Is there any more of them that be Knights?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Aye his brother.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Then kneel down Dicke Butcher,
Rise up sir Dicke Butcher.
Now sound up the Drum.

div2.stage: Enter sir Humphrey Stafford and his brother, with Drumme and souldiers.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: As for these silken coated slaves I pass not a pin,
It is to you good people that I speak.

sp.speaker: Stafford.
sp.l: Why country-men, what mean you thus in troops,
To follow this rebellious Traitor Cade?
Why his father was but a Bricklayer.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Well, and Adam was a Gardner, what then?
But I come of the Mortemers.

sp.speaker: Stafford.
sp.l: Aye, the Duke of Yorke hath taught you that.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: The Duke of York, nay, I learnt it myself,
For look you, Roger Mortemer the Earl of March,
Married the Duke of Clarence daughter.

sp.speaker: Stafford.
sp.l: Well, that is true: But what then?

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: And by her he had two children at a birth.

sp.speaker: Stafford.
sp.l: That is false.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Aye, but I say, it is true.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Why then it is true.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: And one of them was stolen away by a beggar-woman,
And that was my father, and I am his son,
Deny it if you can.

sp.speaker: Nicke.
sp.l: Nay look you, I know it was true,
For his father built a chimney in my fathers house,
And the bricks are alive at this day to testify.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: But doest thou hear Stafford, tell the King, that for his
fathers sake, in whose time boys played at span-counter with
French Crowns, I am content that he shall be King as long
as he lives Marry always provided, I will be Protector over him.

sp.speaker: Stafford.
sp.l: O monstrous simplicity.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: And tell him, we will have the Lord Sayes head, and the
Duke of Somersets, for delivering up the Dukedoms of Anioy
and Mayne, and selling the Towns in France, by which means
England hath been maimed ever since, and gone as it were with a
crouch, but that my puissance held it up. And besides, they can
speak French, and therefore they are traitors.

sp.speaker: Stafford.
sp.l: As how I prithee?

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Why the French men are our enemies be they not?
And then can he that speaks with the tongue of an enemy be a
good subject?
Answer me to that.

sp.speaker: Stafford.
sp.l: Well sirrah, wilt thou yield thyself unto the Kings
mercy, and he will pardon thee and these, their outrages and rebellious deeds?

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Nay, bid the King come to me if he will, and then I will
pardon him, or otherways I will have his Crown tell him, ere it be
long.

sp.speaker: Stafford.
sp.l: Go Herald, proclaim in all the Kings Towns,
That those that will forsake the Rebel Cade,
Shall have free pardon from his Majesty.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Come sirs, saint George for us and Kent.

div2.stage: Alarums to the battaile, and sir Humphrey Stafford and his brother is slaine. Then enter Iacke Cade againe and the rest.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Sir Dicke Butcher, thou hast fought today most valiantly,
And knocked them down as if thou hadst been in thy slaughter house.
And thus I will reward thee. The Lent shall be as long again as
it was. Thou shalt have licence to kill for four score and one a week.
Drum strike up, for now we will march to London, for tomorrow
I mean to sit in the Kings seat at Westminster.

div2.stage: Enter the King reading of a Letter, and the Queene, with the Duke of Suffolkes head, and the Lord Say, with others.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sir Humphrey Stafford and his brother is slain,
And the Rebels march amain to London,
Go back to them, and tell them thus from me.
I will come and parley with their general.

sp.speaker: Reade.
sp.l: Yet stay, I will read the Letter one again.
Lord Say, Iacke Cade hath solemnly vowed to have thy head.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Aye, but I hope your highness shall have his.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How now Madam, still lamenting and mourning for
Suffolkes death, I fear my love, if I had been dead, thou wouldst not
have mourned so much for me.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: No my love, I should not mourn, but die for thee.

sp.speaker: Messenger.
sp.l: O fly my Lord, the Rebels are entered
Southwarke, and have almost won the Bridge,
Calling your grace an usurper,
And that monstrous Rebel Cade, hath sworn
To Crown himself King in Westminster,
Therefore fly my Lord, and post to Killingworth.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Go bid Buckingham and Clifford, gather
An Army up, and meet with the Rebels.
Come Madam, let us haste to Killingworth.
Come on Lord Say, go thou along with us,
For fear the Rebel Cade do find thee out.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: My innocence my Lord shall plead for me.
And therefore with your highness leave, I will stay behind.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Even as thou wilt my Lord Say.
Come Madam, let us go.

div2.stage: Enter the Lord Skayles vpon the Tower walles walking. Enter three or foure Citizens below.

sp.speaker: Lord Scayles.
sp.l: How now, is Iacke Cade slain?

sp.speaker: I. Citizen.
sp.l: No my Lord, nor likely to be slain,
For they have won the bridge,
Killing all those that withstand them.
The Lord Mayor craveth aid of your honour from the Tower,
To defend the City from the Rebels.

sp.speaker: Lord Scayles.
sp.l: Such aid as I can spare, you shall command,
But I am troubled here with them myself,
The Rebels have attempted to win the Tower,
But get you to Smythfield and gather head,
And thither I will send you Mathew Goffe,
Fight for your King, your Country, and your lives,
And so farewell, for I must hence again.

div2.stage: Enter Iacke Cade and the rest and strikes his sword vpon London stone.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Now is Mortemer Lord of this City,
And now sitting upon London stone, We command,
That the first year of our reign,
The pissing Cundit run nothing but red wine.
And now hence forward, it shall be treason
For any that calls me any otherwise than
Lord Mortemer.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.l: Iacke Cade, Iacke Cade.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: 'swounds, knock him down.

sp.speaker: Dicke.
sp.l: My Lord, there is an Army gathered together
Into Smythfield.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Come then, let us go fight with them,
But first go on and set London bridge afire,
And if you can, burn down the Tower too.
Come let us away.

div2.stage: Alarmes, and then Mathew Goffe is slaine, and all the rest with him. Then enter Iacke Cade again, and his company.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: So, sirs now go some and pull down the Sauoy,
Others to the Inns of the Court, down with them all.

sp.speaker: Dicke.
sp.l: I have a suit unto your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Be it a Lordship Dicke, and thou shalt have it
For that word.

sp.speaker: Dicke.
sp.l: That we may go burn all the Records,
And that all writing may be put down,
And nothing used but the score and the Tally.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.p:
Dicke it shall be so, and henceforward all things shall be
in common, and in Cheapeside shall my palfrey go to grass.
Why is it not a miserable thing, that of the skin of an innocent lamb
should parchment be made, and then with a little blotting over with
ink, a man should undo himself. Some says it is the bees that7H61; sting, but I say, it is their wax, for I am sure I never sealed to anything but once, and I was never mine own man since.

sp.speaker: Nicke.
sp.l: But when shall we take up those commodities
Which you told us of.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Marry he that will lustily stand to it,
Shall go with me, and take up these commodities following:
Item, a gown, a kirtle, a petticoat, and a smock.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: My Lord, a prize, a prize, here is the Lord Say,
Which sold the Towns in France.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Come hither thou Say, thou George, thou buckram lord,
What answer canst thou make unto my mightiness,
For delivering up the towns in France to Monsieur bus mine cue,
the Dolphin of France?
sp.p:
And more than so, thou hast most traitorously erected a grammar
school, to infect the youth of the realm, and against the Kings
Crown and dignity, thou hast built up a paper-mill, nay it will be
said to thy face, that thou keepest men in thy house that daily reads
of books with red letters, and talks of a Noun and a Verb, and
such abominable words as no Christian ear is able to endure it.
And besides all that, thou hast appointed certain Justices of peace
in every shire to hang honest men that steal for their living, and
because they could not read, thou hast hung them up: Only for
which cause they were most worthy to live. Thou ridest on a foot cloth doest thou not?

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.p: Yes, what of that?

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.p:
Marry I say, thou oughtest not to let thy horse wear a
cloak, when an honester man than thyself, goes in his hose and
doublet.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.p: You men of Kent.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Kent, what of Kent?

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.p: Nothing but bona, terra.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.p: Bonum terum, sounds whats that?

sp.speaker: Dicke.
sp.p: He speaks French.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: No it is Dutch.

sp.speaker: Nicke.
sp.p: No it is italian, I know it well enough.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Kent, in the Commentaries Caesar wrote,
Termed it the civilest place of all this land,
Then noble Country-men, hear me but speak,
I sold not France, I lost not Normandie.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.p: But wherefore doest thou shake thy head so?

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: It is the palsy and not fear that makes me.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.p:
Nay thou noddest thy head, as who say, thou wilt be even
with me, if thou gettest away, but I will make the sure enough, now I
have thee. Go take him to the standard in Cheapeside and chop off
his head, and then go to milende-greene, to sir Iames Cromer his
son in law, and cut off his head too, and bring them to me upon
two poles presently. Away with him.

div2.stage: Exet one or two, with the Lord Say.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: There shall not a noble man wear a head on his shoulders,
But he shall pay me tribute for it.
Nor there shall not a maid be married, but he shall fee to me for her.
Maidenhead or else, I will have it myself,
Marry I will that married men shall hold of me in capitie,
And that their wives shall be as free as heart can think, or tongue can

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: O Captain, London bridge is afire.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.p:
Run to Billingsgate, and fetch pitch and flax and
squench it.

sp.speaker: Sargiant.
sp.p:
Justice, justice, I pray you sir, let me have justice of this
fellow here.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.p: Why what has he done?

sp.speaker: Sarg.
sp.p: Alas sir he has ravished my wife.

sp.speaker: Dicke.
sp.l: Why my Lord he would have rested me,
And I went and and entered my Action in his wives paper house.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Dicke follow thy suit in her common place,
You whoreson villain, you are a Sargiant you will,
Take any man by the throat for twelve pence,
And rest a man when he is at dinner,
And have him to prison ere the meat be out of his mouth.
Go Dicke take him hence, cut out his tongue for cogging,
Hough him for running, and to conclude,
Brave him with his own mace.

div2.stage: Exet with the Sargiant. Enter two with the Lord Sayes head, and sir Iames Cromers, vpon two poles.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: So, come carry them before me, and at every lanes end, let them
kiss together.

div2.stage: Enter the Duke of Buckingham, and Lord Clifford the Earle of Comberland.

sp.speaker: Clifford.
sp.l: Why country-men and warlike friends of Kent,
What means this mutinous rebellions,
That you in troops do muster thus yourselves,
Under the conduct of this Traitor Cade?
To rise against your sovereign Lord and King,
Who mildly hath his pardon sent to you,
If you forsake this monstrous Rebel here?
If honour be the mark whereat you aim,
Then haste to France that our forefathers won,
And win again that thing which now is lost
And leave to seek your Countries overthrow.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A Clifford, a Clifford.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Why how now, will you forsake your general,
And ancient freedom which you have possessed?
To bend your necks under their servile yokes,
Who if you stir, will straightaways hang you up,
But follow me, and you shall pull them down,
And make them yield their livings to your hands.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A Cade, a Cade.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Brave warlike friends hear me but speak a word,
Refuse not good whilst it is offered you,
The King is merciful, then yield to him,
And I myself will go along with you,
To Winsore Castle whereas the King abides,
And on mine honour you shall have no hurt.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A Clifford, a Clifford, God save the King.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: How like a feather is this rascal company
Blown every way,
But that they may see there want no valiance in me,
My staff shall make way through the midst of you,
And so a pox take you all.

div2.stage: He runs through them with his staffe, and flies away.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: Go some and make after him, and proclaim,
That those that can bring the head of Cade,
Shall have a thousand Crowns for his labour.
Come march away.

div2.stage: Enter King Henry and the Queene, and Somerset.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Lord Somerset, what news here you of the Rebel Cade?

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: This, my gracious Lord, that the Lord Say is don to death,
And the City is almost sacked.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Gods will be done, for as he hath decreed, so must it be:
And be it as he please, to stop the pride of those rebellious men.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Had the noble Duke of Suffolke been alive,
The Rebel Cade had been suppressed ere this,
And all the rest that do take part with him.

div2.stage: Enter the Duke of Buckingham and Clifford, with the Rebels, with halters about their necks.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Long live King Henry, Englands lawful King,
Lo here my Lord, these Rebels are subdued,
And offer their lives before your highness feet.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But tell me Clifford, is their Captain here.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.p:
No, my gracious Lord, he is fled away, but proclamations
are sent forth, that he that can but bring his head, shall have a thousand
crowns. But may it please your Majesty, to pardon these
their faults, that by that traitors means were thus misled.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Stand up you simple men, and give God praise,
For you did take in hand you know not what,
And go in peace obedient to your King,
And live as subjects, and you shall not want,
Whilst Henry lives, and wears the English Crown.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: God save the King, God save the King.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come let us haste to London now with speed,
That solemn processions may be sung,
In laud and honour of the God of heaven,
And triumphs of this happy victory.

div2.stage: Enter Iacke Cade at one doore, and at the other, maister Alexander Eyden and his men, and Iack Cade lies downe picking of hearbes and eating them.

sp.speaker: Eyden.
sp.l: Good Lord how pleasant is this country life,
This little land my father left me here,
With my contented mind serves me as well,
As all the pleasures in the Court can yield,
Nor would I change this pleasure for the Court.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.p:
'swounds, here is the Lord of the soil, Stand villain, thou
wilt betray me to the King, and get a thousand crowns for my
head, but ere thou goest, I will make thee eat iron like an Astridge,
and swallow my sword like a great pin.

sp.speaker: Eyden.
sp.l: Why saucy companion, why should I betray thee?
Is it not enough that thou hast broke my hedges,
And entered into my ground without the leave of me the owner,
But thou wilt brave me too.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.p:
Brave thee and beard thee too, by the best blood of the
Realm, look on me well, I have eat no meat this five days, yet
and I do not leave thee and thy five men as dead as a door nail, I
pray God I may never eat grass more.

sp.speaker: Eyden.
sp.p:
Nay, it never shall be said whilst the world doth stand,
that Alexander Eyden an Esquire of Kent, took odds to combat
with a famished man, look on me, my limbs are equal unto thine,
and every way as big, then hand to hand, I will combat thee. Sirrah
fetch me weapons, and stand you all aside.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.p:
Now sword, if thou doest not hew this burly-bond churl
into chines of beef, I beseech God thou mayest fall into some smiths
hand, and be turned to hobnails.

sp.speaker: Eyden.
sp.p: Come on thy way.

div2.stage: They fight, and Cade fals downe.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.p:
O villain, thou hast slain the flower of Kent for chivalry,
but it is famine and not thee that has done it, for come ten thousand
devils, and give me but the ten meals that I wanted this five
days, and I will fight with you all, and so a pox rot thee, for Iacke
Cade must die.

sp.speaker: Eyden.
sp.p:
Iack Cade, and was it that monstrous Rebel which I have
slain. O sword I will honour thee for this, and in my chamber shalt
thou hang as a monument to after age, for this great service thou
hast done to me. I will drag him hence, and with my sword cut off his
head, and bear it to the King.

div2.stage: Enter the Duke of Yorke with Drum and souldiers,

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: In Arms from Ireland comes Yorke amain,
Ring bells aloud, bonfires perfume the air,
To entertain fair Englands royal King.
Ah Sancta Maiesta, who would not buy thee dear?

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: But soft, who comes here Buckingham, what news with him?

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: Yorke, if thou mean well, I greet thee so.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Humphrey of Buckingham, welcome I swear:
What comes thou in love or as a Messenger?

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: I come as a Messenger from our dread Lord and sovereign,
Henry. To know the reason of these Arms in peace?
Or that thou being a subject as I am,
Shouldst thus approach so near with colours spread,
Whereas the person of the King doth keep?

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: A subject as he is.
O how I hate these spiteful abject terms,
But Yorke dissemble, till thou meet thy sons,
Who now in Arms expect their fathers sight,
And not far hence I know they cannot be.
Humphrey Duke of Buckingham, pardon me,
That I answered not at first, my mind was troubled,
I came to remove that monstrous Rebel Cade,
And heave proud Somerset from out the Court,
That basely yielded up the Towns in France.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: Why that was presumption on thy behalf,
But if it be no otherwise but so,
The King doth pardon thee, and grantest to thy request,
And Somerset is sent unto the Tower.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Upon thine honour is it so?

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: Yorke, he is upon mine honour.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Then before thy face, I here dismiss my troops,
Sirs, meet me tomorrow in saint Georges fields,
And there you shall receive your pay of me.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: Come York, thou shalt go speak unto the King,
But see, his grace is coming to meet with us.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How now Buckingham, is Yorke friends with us,
That thus thou bringest him hand in hand with thee?

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: He is my Lord, and hath discharged his troops
Which came with him, but as your grace did say,
To heave the Duke of Somerset from hence,
And to subdue the Rebels that were up.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Then welcome cousin Yorke, give me thy hand,
And thanks for thy great service done to us,
Against those traitorous Irish that rebelled.

div2.stage: Enter maister Eyden with Iacke Cades head.

sp.speaker: Eyden.
sp.l: Long live Henry in triumphant peace,
Lo here my Lord upon my bended knees,
I here present the traitorous head of Cade,
That hand to hand in single fight I slew.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: First thanks to heaven, and next to thee my friend,
That hast subdued that wicked traitor thus.
O let me see that head that in his life,
Did work me and my land such cruel spite,
A visage stern, cole black his curled locks,
Deep trenched furrows in his frowning brow,
Presageth warlike humours in his life.
Here take it hence and thou for thy reward,
Shalt be immediately created Knight.
Kneel down my friend, and tell me what is thy name?

sp.speaker: Eyden.
sp.l: Alexander Eyden, if it please your grace,
A poor Esquire of Kent.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Then rise up sir Alexander Eyden knight,
And for thy maintenance, I freely give
A thousand marks a year to maintain thee,
Beside the firm reward that was proclaimed,
For those that could perform this worthy act,
And thou shalt wait upon the person of the king.

sp.speaker: Eyden.
sp.l: I humbly thank your grace, and I no longer live,
Then I prove just and loyal to my king.

div2.stage: Exet. Enter the Queene with the Duke of Somerset.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O Buckingham see where Somerset comes,
Bid him go hide himself till Yorke be gone.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: He shall not hide himself for fear of Yorke,
But beard and brave him proudly to his face.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Who is that, proud Somerset at liberty?
Base fearful Henry that thus dishonourest me,
By heaven, thou shalt not govern over me:
I cannot brooke that Traitors presence here,
Nor will I subject be to such a King,
That knows not how to govern nor to rule,
Resign thy Crown proud Lancaster to me,
That thou usurped hast so long by force,
For now is Yorke resolved to claim his own,
And rise aloft into fair Englands Throne.

sp.speaker: Somer.
sp.l: Proud Traitor, I arrest thee on high treason,
Against thy sovereign Lord, yield thee false Yorke,
For here I swear, thou shalt unto the Tower,
For these proud words which thou hast given the king.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Thou art deceived, my sons shall be my bail,
And send thee there in despite of him.
Ho, where are you boys?

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Call Clifford hither presently.

div2.stage: Enter the Duke of Yorkes sonnes, Edward the Earle of March, and crook-backe Richard, at the one doore, with Drumme and soldiers, and at the other doore, enter Clifford and his sonne, with Drumme and souldiers, and Clifford kneeles to Henry, and speakes.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Long live my noble Lord, and sovereign King.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: We thank thee Clifford.
Nay, do not affright us with thy looks,
If thou didst mistake, we pardon thee, kneel again.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Why, I did no way mistake, this is my King.
What is he mad? to Bedlam with him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Aye, a bedlam frantic humour drives him thus
To levy Arms against his lawful King.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Why doth not your grace send him to the Tower?

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: He is arrested, but will not obey,
His sons he saith, shall be his bail.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: How say you boys, will you not?

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Yes noble father, if our words will serve.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: And if our words will not, our swords shall.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Call hither to the stake, my two rough bears.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Call Buckingham, and bid him Arm himself.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Call Buckingham and all the friends thou hast,
Both thou and they, shall curse this fatal hour.

div2.stage: Enter at one doore, the Earles of Salsbury and Warwicke, with Drumme and souldiers. And at the other, the Duke of Buckingham, with Drumme and souldiers.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Are these thy bears? we will bait them soon,
Despite of thee and all the friends thou hast.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: You had best go dream again,
To keep you from the tempest of the field.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: I am resolved to bear a greater storm,
Then any thou canst conjure up today,
And that I will write upon thy Burganet,
Might I but know thee by thy household badge.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Now by my fathers age, old Neuels crest,
The Rampant Bear chained to the ragged staff,
This day I will wear aloft my burganet,
As on a mountain top the Cedar shows,
That keeps his leaves in spite of any storm,
Even to affright the with the view thereof.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: And from thy burganet will I rend the bear,
And tread him underfoot with all contempt,
Despite the Bearward that protects him so.

sp.speaker: Yoong Clif.
sp.l: And so renowned sovereign to Arms,
To quell these Traitors and their accomplices.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: Fie, Charity for shame, speak it not in spite,
For you shall sup with Iesus Christ tonight.

sp.speaker: Yoong Clif.
sp.l: Foul Stigmatic thou canst not tell.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: No, for if not in heaven, you will surely sup in hell.

div2.stage: Alarmes to the battaile, and then enter the Duke of Somerset and Richard fighting, and Richard kils him vnder the signe of the Castle in saint Albones.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: So Lie thou there, and breathe thy last.
What is here, the sign of the Castle?
Then the prophecy is come to pass,
For Somerset was forewarned of Castles,
The which he always did observe.
And now behold, under a paltry Ale-house sign,
The Castle in saint Albones,
Somerset hath made the Wizard famous by his death.

div2.stage: Exet. Alarme again, and enter the Earle of Warwicke alone.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Clifford of Comberland, it is Warwicke calls,
And if thou doest not hide thee from the Bear,
Now whilst the angry Trumpets sound Alarms,
And dead men's cries do fill the empty air:
Clifford I say, come forth and fight with me,
Proud Northern Lord, Clifford of Comberland,
Warwicke is hoarse with calling thee to Arms.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Warwicke stand still, and view the way that Clifford hews with
his murthering Curtle-axe, through the fainting troops to find
thee out.
Warwicke stand still, and stir not till I come.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: How now my Lord, what a foot?
Who killed your horse?

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: The deadly hand of Clifford. Noble Lord,
Five horse this day slain under me,
And yet brave Warwicke I remain alive,
But I did kill his horse he loved so well,
The boniest gray that ere was bred in North.

div2.stage: Enter Clifford, and Warwicke offers to fight with him.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Hold Warwicke, and seek thee out some other chase,
Myself will hunt this deer to death.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Brave Lord, it is for a Crown thou fights,
Clifford farewell, as I intend to prosper well today,
It grieves my soul to leave thee unassailed.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Now Clifford, since we are singled here alone,
Be this the day of doom to one of us,
For now my heart hath sworn immortal hate
To thee and all the house of Lancaster.

sp.speaker: Cliffood.
sp.l: And here I stand, and pitch my foot to thine,
Vowing never to stir, till thou or I be slain.
For never shall my heart be safe at rest,
Till I have spoiled the hateful house of Yorke.

div2.stage: Alarmes, and they fight, and Yorke kils Clifford.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Now Lancaster sit sure, thy sinews shrink,
Come fearful Henry grovelling on thy face,
Yield up thy Crown unto the Prince of Yorke.

div2.stage: Exet Yorke. Alarmes, then enter yoong Clifford alone.

sp.speaker: Yoong Clifford.
sp.l: Father of Comberland,
Where may I seek my aged father forth?
O! dismal sight, see where he breathless lies,
All smeared and weltered in his lukewarm blood,
Ah, aged pillar of all Comberlands true house,
Sweet father, to thy murthered ghost I swear,
Immortal hate unto the house of Yorke,
Nor never shall I sleep secure one night,
Till I have furiously revenged thy death,
And left not one of them to breath on earth.

div2.stage: He takes him vp on his backe.

sp.speaker: Yoong Clifford.
sp.l: And thus as old Ankyses son did bear
His aged father on his manly back,
And fought with him against the bloody Greeks,
Even so will I. But stay, here is one of them,
To whom my soul hath sworn immortal hate.

div2.stage: Enter Richard, and then Clifford laies downe his father, fights with him, and Richard flies away againe.

sp.speaker: Yoong Clifford.
sp.l: Out crooked-back villain, get thee from my sight,
But I will after thee, and once again
When I have borne my father to his Tent,
I will try my fortune better with thee yet.

div2.stage: Exet yoong Clifford with his father. Alarmes againe, and then enter three or foure, bearing the Duke of Buckingham wounded to his Tent. Alarmes still, and then enter the King and Queene.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Away my Lord, and fly to London straight,
Make haste, for vengeance comes along with them,
Come stand not to expostulate, let us go.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come then fair Queen to London let us haste,
And summon a Parliament with speed,
To stop the fury of these dire events.

div2.stage: Alarmes, and then a flourish, and enter the Duke of Yorke and Richard.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: How now boys, fortunate this fight hath been,
I hope to us and ours, for Englands good,
And our great honour, that so long we lost,
Whilst faint-heart Henry did usurp our rights:
But did you see old Salsbury, since we
With bloody minds did buckle with the foe,
I would not for the loss of this right hand,
That ought but well betide that good old man.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: My Lord, I saw him in the thickest throng,
Charging his Lance with his old weary arms,
And thrice I saw him beaten from his horse,
And thrice this hand did set him up again,
And still he fought with courage against his foes,
The boldest spirited man that ere mine eyes beheld.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: See noble father, where they both do come,
The only props unto the house of Yorke.

sp.speaker: Salsb.
sp.l: Well hast thou fought this day, thou valiant Duke,
And thou brave bud of Yorkes increasing house,
The small remainder of my weary life,
I hold for thee, for with thy warlike arm,
Three times this day thou hast preserved my life.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: What say you Lords, the King is fled to London?
There as I hear to hold a Parliament.
What says Lord Warwicke, shall we after them?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: After them, nay before them if we can.
Now by my faith Lords, it was a glorious day,
Saint Albones battle won by famous Yorke,
Shall be eternized in all age to come.
Sound Drums and Trumpets, and to London all,
And more such days as these to us befall.
